This article is about the reign of King Edward VII in the 20th century. For
use of the term Edwardian in medieval English history, see [Edward I of

The **Edwardian era** or **Edwardian period** of [British
history](/wiki/History_of_the_United_Kingdom "History of the United Kingdom")
covers the brief reign of [King Edward VII](/wiki/King_Edward_VII "King Edward
VII"), 1901 to 1910, and is sometimes extended in both directions to capture
long-term trends from the 1890s to the [First World War](/wiki/World_War_I
"World War I"). The death of [Queen Victoria](/wiki/Queen_Victoria "Queen
Victoria") in January 1901 marked the end of the [Victorian
era](/wiki/Victorian_era "Victorian era"). The new king Edward VII was already
the leader of a fashionable elite that set a style influenced by the art and
fashions of continental Europe. [Samuel Hynes](/wiki/Samuel_Hynes "Samuel
Hynes") described the Edwardian era as a "leisurely time when women wore
[picture hats](/wiki/Picture_hat "Picture hat") and did not vote, when the
rich were not ashamed to live conspicuously, and the sun really never set on
the British flag'".[1] The Liberals returned to power in
[1906](/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_1906 "United Kingdom general
election, 1906") and made [significant reforms](/wiki/Liberal_welfare_reforms
"Liberal welfare reforms"). Below the upper class, the era was marked by
significant shifts in politics among sections of society that were largely
excluded from wielding power in the past, such as common labourers. Women
became increasingly politicised.[2]

## Perceptions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Perceptions")]

The Edwardian period is sometimes portrayed as a romantic golden age of long
summer afternoons and garden parties, basking in a sun that never sets on the
[British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire"). This perception was
created in the 1920s and later by those who remembered the Edwardian age with
nostalgia, looking back to their childhoods across the abyss of the [Great
War](/wiki/Great_War "Great War").[3] The Edwardian age was also seen as a
mediocre period of pleasure between the great achievements of the preceding
Victorian age and the catastrophe of the following war.[4] Since 2000
historiographical assessments emphasise the great differences between the
wealthy and the poor during this period and describe the age as heralding
great changes in political and social life.[2][5] Historian [Lawrence
James](/wiki/Lawrence_James "Lawrence James") has argued that the leaders felt
increasingly threatened by rival powers such as Germany, Russia, and the
United States.[6] The sudden arrival of world war in summer 1914 was
completely unexpected; only the Royal Navy was prepared for war.

## Politics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Politics")]

There was a growing political awareness of the [working-class](/wiki/Working-
class "Working-class"), leading to a rise in [trade unions](/wiki/Trade_unions
"Trade unions"), the [Labour movement](/wiki/Labour_movement "Labour
movement") and demands for better working conditions. The aristocracy remained
in control of top government offices.[7]

### Conservative
Party[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Conservative Party")]

Main article: [History of the Conservative Party
(UK)](/wiki/History_of_the_Conservative_Party_\(UK\) "History of the
Conservative Party \(UK\)")

The [Conservatives](/wiki/Conservative_Party_\(UK\) "Conservative Party
\(UK\)") – at the time called "Unionists" – were the dominant political party
from the 1890s until [1906](/wiki/1906_UK_general_election "1906 UK general
election"). The party had many strengths, appealing to voters supportive of
[imperialism](/wiki/Imperialism "Imperialism"), tariffs, the [Church of
England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of England"), a powerful [Royal
Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy"), and traditional hierarchical society.
There was a powerful leadership base in the landed aristocracy and landed
gentry in rural England, plus strong support from the Church of England and
military interests. Historians have used election returns to demonstrate that
Conservatives did surprisingly well in working-class districts.[8][9] They had
an appeal as well to the better-off element of traditional working-class
Britons in the larger cities.[10] In rural areas, the national headquarters
made highly effective use of paid traveling lecturers, with pamphlets,
posters, and especially lantern slides, who were able to communicate
effectively with rural voters – particularly the newly enfranchised
agricultural workers.[11] In the first years of the twentieth century, the
Conservative government, with [Arthur Balfour](/wiki/Arthur_Balfour "Arthur
Balfour") as [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom
"Prime Minister of the United Kingdom"), had numerous successes in foreign
policy, defence, and education, as well as solutions for the issues of alcohol
licensing and land ownership for the peasants of Ireland.[12]

Nevertheless, the weaknesses were accumulating, and proved so overwhelming in
1906 that they did not return to complete power until
[1922](/wiki/1922_UK_general_election "1922 UK general election").[13] The
Conservative Party was losing its drive and enthusiasm, especially after the
retirement of the charismatic [Joseph Chamberlain](/wiki/Joseph_Chamberlain
"Joseph Chamberlain"). There was a bitter split on ["tariff
reform"](/wiki/Protectionism "Protectionism") (that is, imposing tariffs or
taxes on all imports), that drove many of the free traders over to the
[Liberal](/wiki/Liberal_Party_\(UK\) "Liberal Party \(UK\)") camp. Tariff
reform was a losing issue that the Conservative leadership inexplicably clung
to.[14] Support among the top tier of the working-class, and in lower middle-
class weakened, and there was dissatisfaction among the intellectuals. The
1906 general election was a landslide victory for the Liberal Party, which saw
its total vote share increase by 25%, while the Conservative total vote held
steady.[15]

### Liberal
Party[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Liberal Party")]

Main article: [Liberal Party (UK)](/wiki/Liberal_Party_\(UK\) "Liberal Party
\(UK\)")

The Liberal Party lacked a unified ideological base in 1906.[16] It contained
numerous contradictory and hostile factions, such as imperialists and
supporters of the Boers;[17] near-socialists and laissez-faire classical
liberals; suffragettes and opponents of women's suffrage;[18] antiwar elements
and supporters of the military alliance with France.[19] Non-Conformist
Dissenters – Protestants outside the Anglican fold – were a powerful element,
dedicated to opposing the established church in terms of education and
taxation. However, the Dissenters were losing support and society at large and
played a lesser and lesser role in party affairs after 1900.[20] The Party,
furthermore, also included [Irish Catholics](/wiki/Irish_Catholics "Irish
Catholics"), and secularists from the labour movement. The middle-class
business, professional and intellectual communities were generally
strongholds, although some old aristocratic families played important roles as
well. The working-class element was moving rapidly toward the newly emerging
[Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Party_\(UK\) "Labour Party \(UK\)"). One uniting
element was widespread agreement on the use of politics and Parliament as a
device to upgrade and improve society and to reform politics.[21]

### Labour Party[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Labour Party")]

Main article: [History of the Labour Party
(UK)](/wiki/History_of_the_Labour_Party_\(UK\) "History of the Labour Party
\(UK\)")

The Labour Party was emerging from the rapidly growing trade union movement
after 1890. In 1903 it entered the [Gladstone–MacDonald
pact](/wiki/Gladstone%E2%80%93MacDonald_pact "Gladstone–MacDonald pact") with
the Liberals, allowing for cross-party support in elections, and the emergence
of a small Labour contingent in Parliament. It was a temporary arrangement
until the 1920s, when the Labour Party was strong enough to act on its own,
and the Liberals were in an irreversible decline. Subtle social changes in the
working-class were producing a younger generation that wanted to act
independently. Michael Childs argues that the younger generation had reason to
prefer Labour over Liberal political styles. Social factors included
secularised elementary education (with a disappearing role for Dissenting
schools that inculcated Liberal viewpoints); the "New Unionism" after 1890
brought unskilled workers into a movement previously dominated by the skilled
workers;[22] and new leisure activities, especially the [music
hall](/wiki/Music_hall "Music hall") and sports, involved youth while
repelling the older generation of Liberal voters.[23]

### Boer War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Boer War")]

Main article: [Opposition to the Second Boer
War](/wiki/Opposition_to_the_Second_Boer_War "Opposition to the Second Boer
War")

The government entered the [Second Boer War](/wiki/Second_Boer_War "Second
Boer War") with great confidence, little expecting that the two small rural
Boer republics in southern Africa with a combined White population less than
London would hold off the concentrated power of the [British
Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") for two and half years, and
take 400,000 Imperial troops to secure victory.[24] The war split the Liberal
Party into anti- and pro-war factions. Great orators, such as Liberal [David
Lloyd George](/wiki/David_Lloyd_George "David Lloyd George"), who spoke
against the war, became increasingly influential. Nevertheless Liberal
Unionist [Joseph Chamberlain](/wiki/Joseph_Chamberlain "Joseph Chamberlain"),
who was largely in charge of the war, maintained his hold on power. When
[General Kitchener](/wiki/Herbert_Kitchener "Herbert Kitchener") took command
in 1900, he initiated a scorched earth policy in order to foil Boer guerilla
tactics. Captured Boer combatants were transported overseas to other British
possessions as prisoners of war. However he relocated noncombatant
Boers—mostly women and children—into heavily guarded internment camps. The
internment camps were overcrowded with bad sanitation and meagre food rations.
Contagious diseases such as measles, typhoid and dysentery were endemic. Many
of the internees died. [Emily Hobhouse](/wiki/Emily_Hobhouse "Emily Hobhouse")
visited the camps and brought the conditions to the attention of the British
public. Public outcry resulted in the [Fawcett
Commission](/wiki/Millicent_Fawcett "Millicent Fawcett") which corroborated
Hobhouse's report and eventually led to improved conditions.[25] The Boers
surrendered and the Boer Republics were annexed by the British Empire. [Jan
Smuts](/wiki/Jan_Smuts "Jan Smuts")—a leading Boer general—became a senior
official of the new government and even became a top British official in the
World War.[26]

In 1901, the six British self-governing colonies of Queensland, New South
Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia, and Western Australia united to
form the Commonwealth of Australia, with almost complete control of its
internal affairs, but with foreign policy and defence handled by London.
[Edmund Barton](/wiki/Edmund_Barton "Edmund Barton") was the first prime
minister.[27]

### The Liberal
reforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: The Liberal reforms")]

Further information: [Liberal welfare reforms](/wiki/Liberal_welfare_reforms
"Liberal welfare reforms")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Ten_Years_of_Toryism.jpg/220px-
Ten_Years_of_Toryism.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ten_Years_of_Toryism.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ten_Years_of_Toryism.jpg "Enlarge")

Liberal poster c.1905–10

The [Liberal Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_\(UK\) "Liberal Party \(UK\)") under
[Henry Campbell-Bannerman](/wiki/Henry_Campbell-Bannerman "Henry Campbell-
Bannerman") rallied Liberals around the traditional platform of free trade and
land reform and led them to [the greatest electoral
victory](/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_1906 "United Kingdom general
election, 1906") in Liberal Party history.[28] The [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom "Prime Minister of the
United Kingdom") was overshadowed by his frontbench, most notably [H. H.
Asquith](/wiki/H._H._Asquith "H. H. Asquith") at the Exchequer, [Edward
Grey](/wiki/Edward_Grey,_1st_Viscount_Grey_of_Fallodon "Edward Grey, 1st
Viscount Grey of Fallodon") at the Foreign Office, [Richard Burdon
Haldane](/wiki/Richard_Burdon_Haldane,_1st_Viscount_Haldane "Richard Burdon
Haldane, 1st Viscount Haldane") at the War Office and [David Lloyd
George](/wiki/David_Lloyd_George "David Lloyd George") at the [Board of
Trade](/wiki/Board_of_Trade "Board of Trade"). Campbell-Bannerman retired in
1908 and was succeeded by Asquith. He stepped up the government's radicalism,
especially in the "[People's Budget](/wiki/People%27s_Budget "People's
Budget")" of 1909 that proposed to fund expanded social welfare programmes
with new taxes on land and high incomes. It was blocked by the Conservative-
dominated [House of Lords](/wiki/House_of_Lords "House of Lords"), but
eventually became law in April 1910.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Asquith_Q_42036.jpg/220px-
Asquith_Q_42036.jpg)](/wiki/File:Asquith_Q_42036.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Asquith_Q_42036.jpg "Enlarge")

[H. H. Asquith](/wiki/H._H._Asquith "H. H. Asquith")

Almost half of the Liberal MPs elected in 1906 were supportive of the '[New
Liberalism](/wiki/Social_liberalism "Social liberalism")', which advocated
government action to improve people's lives.[29]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Punch_cartoon_28_April_1909.jpg/280px-
Punch_cartoon_28_April_1909.jpg)](/wiki/File:Punch_cartoon_28_April_1909.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Punch_cartoon_28_April_1909.jpg "Enlarge")

"Wild Fare". Cartoonist [John Bernard Partridge](/wiki/John_Bernard_Partridge
"John Bernard Partridge") depicts Lloyd George as a giant with a cudgel
labelled "Budget" in reference to his [People's
Budget](/wiki/People%27s_Budget "People's Budget"); Asquith cowers beneath the
table. _[Punch](/wiki/Punch_\(magazine\) "Punch \(magazine\)")_ 28 April 1909

Liberals in 1906–1911 passed major legislation designed to reform politics and
society, such as the regulation of working hours, [National
Insurance](/wiki/National_Insurance "National Insurance") and the beginnings
of the welfare state, as well as curtailing the power of the House of Lords.
Women's suffrage was not on the Liberal agenda.[30] There were numerous major
reforms helping labour, typified by the [Trade Boards Act
1909](/wiki/Trade_Boards_Act_1909 "Trade Boards Act 1909") that set minimum
wages in certain trades with the history of "sweated" or "sweatshop" rates of
especially low wages, because of surplus of available workers, the presence of
women workers, or the lack of skills. At first it applied to four industries:
chain-making, ready-made tailoring, paper-box making, and the machine-made
lace and finishing trade.[31] It was later expanded to coal mining and then to
other industries with preponderance of unskilled manual labour by the [Trade
Boards Act 1918](/wiki/Trade_Boards_Act_1918 "Trade Boards Act 1918"). Under
the leadership of [David Lloyd George](/wiki/David_Lloyd_George "David Lloyd
George") Liberals extended minimum wages to farm workers.[32]

Conservative peers in the House of Lords tried to stop the [People's
Budget](/wiki/People%27s_Budget "People's Budget"). The Liberals passed the
[Parliament Act 1911](/wiki/Parliament_Act_1911 "Parliament Act 1911") to
sharply reduce the power of the [House of Lords](/wiki/House_of_Lords "House
of Lords") to block legislation. The cost was high, however, as the government
was required by the king to call two general elections in 1910 to validate its
position and ended up frittering away most of its large majority, with the
balance of power held by [Labour](/wiki/Labour_Party_\(UK\) "Labour Party
\(UK\)") and [Irish Parliamentary Party](/wiki/Irish_Parliamentary_Party
"Irish Parliamentary Party") members.

## Foreign
relations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Foreign relations")]

Main articles: [International relations of the Great Powers
(1814–1919)](/wiki/International_relations_of_the_Great_Powers_\(1814%E2%80%931919\)
"International relations of the Great Powers \(1814–1919\)"), [Causes of World
War I](/wiki/Causes_of_World_War_I "Causes of World War I"), and [Timeline of
British diplomatic history](/wiki/Timeline_of_British_diplomatic_history
"Timeline of British diplomatic history")

### Diplomatic ties with France and Russia against
Germany[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Diplomatic ties with France and Russia against Germany")]

Main articles: [France–United Kingdom
relations](/wiki/France%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations "France–United
Kingdom relations") and [Germany–United Kingdom
relations](/wiki/Germany%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations "Germany–United
Kingdom relations")

Germany's Chancellor [Otto von Bismarck](/wiki/Otto_von_Bismarck "Otto von
Bismarck") dominated European diplomacy from 1872-1890, with the determination
to use the balance of power to keep the peace. There were no wars. Bismarck
was removed by an aggressive young Kaiser Wilhelm in 1890, effectively
decentralizing the Bismarckian Order that had been shrewdly managed and
empowering French efforts to isolate Germany. With the formation of the
[Triple Entente](/wiki/Triple_Entente "Triple Entente"), Germany began to feel
encircled: to the West lay France, with whom rivalry was awakening after a
generation of dormancy following the Franco-Prussian War, to the East sat
Russia, whose rapid industrialization worried leaders across the Continent,
and in the seas, British primacy threatened a unified Germany's efforts to
develop its ports and maintain its new global empire.[33] [Joseph
Chamberlain](/wiki/Joseph_Chamberlain "Joseph Chamberlain"), who played a
major role in foreign policy in the late 1890s under the Salisbury government,
repeatedly tried to open talks with Germany about some sort of an alliance.
Germany was not interested.[34] Meanwhile Paris went to great pains to woo
Russia and Great Britain. Key markers were the [Franco-Russian
Alliance](/wiki/Franco-Russian_Alliance "Franco-Russian Alliance") of 1894,
the 1904 [Entente Cordiale](/wiki/Entente_Cordiale "Entente Cordiale") linking
France and Great Britain, and finally the [Anglo-Russian Entente](/wiki/Anglo-
Russian_Entente "Anglo-Russian Entente") in 1907 which became the [Triple
Entente](/wiki/Triple_Entente "Triple Entente"). France thus had a formal
alliance with Russia, and an informal alignment with Britain, against Germany
and Austria.[35] By 1903 good relations had been established with the United
States and Japan.[36]

Britain abandoned the policy of holding aloof from the continental powers, so
called "[Splendid Isolation](/wiki/Splendid_Isolation "Splendid Isolation")",
in the 1900s after being isolated during the [Boer War](/wiki/Boer_War "Boer
War"). Britain concluded agreements, limited to colonial affairs, with her two
major colonial rivals: the [Entente Cordiale](/wiki/Entente_Cordiale "Entente
Cordiale") with France in 1904 and the [Anglo-Russian Entente](/wiki/Anglo-
Russian_Entente "Anglo-Russian Entente") of 1907. Britain's alignment a
reaction to an assertive German foreign policy and the buildup of its navy
from 1898 which led to the [Anglo-German naval arms race](/wiki/Anglo-
German_naval_arms_race "Anglo-German naval arms race").[37] British diplomat
[Arthur Nicolson](/wiki/Arthur_Nicolson,_1st_Baron_Carnock "Arthur Nicolson,
1st Baron Carnock") argued it was "far more disadvantageous to us to have an
unfriendly France and Russia than an unfriendly Germany".[38] The impact of
the Triple Entente was to improve British relations with France and its ally
Russia and to demote the importance to Britain of good relations with Germany.
After 1905, foreign policy was tightly controlled by The Liberal foreign
minister [Edward Grey](/wiki/Edward_Grey,_1st_Viscount_Grey_of_Fallodon
"Edward Grey, 1st Viscount Grey of Fallodon") (1862-1933), who seldom
consulted with his party leadership. Grey shared the strong Liberal policy
against all wars and against military alliances that would force Britain to
take a side in war. However, in the case of the Boer War, Grey held that the
Boers had committed an aggression that it was necessary to repulse. The
Liberal party split on the issue, with a large faction strongly opposed to the
war in Africa [39]

The Triple Entente between Britain, France and Russia is often compared to the
[Triple Alliance](/wiki/Triple_Alliance_\(1882\) "Triple Alliance \(1882\)")
between Germany, Austria–Hungary and Italy, but historians caution against the
comparison. The Entente, in contrast to the Triple Alliance or the [Franco-
Russian Alliance](/wiki/Franco-Russian_Alliance "Franco-Russian Alliance"),
was not an alliance of mutual defence and Britain therefore felt free to make
her own foreign policy decisions in 1914. The Liberals were highly moralistic,
and by 1914 they have been increasingly convinced that German aggression
violated international norms, and specifically that its invasion of neutral
Belgium was completely unacceptable in terms of morality, Britain and
Germany's obligations under the [Treaty of
London](/wiki/Treaty_of_London_\(1839\) "Treaty of London \(1839\)"), and in
terms of British policy against any one power controlling the continent of
Europe.[40]

Until the last few weeks before it started in August 1914, almost no one saw a
world war coming. The expectation among the generals was that because of
industrial advances any future war would produce a quick victory for the side
that was better-prepared, better armed, and faster to move. No one saw that
the innovations of recent decades—high explosives, long-range artillery and
machine guns—were defensive weapons that practically guaranteed defeat of
massed infantry attacks with very high casualties.[41]

### Naval race with
Germany[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Naval race with Germany")]

Main article: [Anglo-German naval arms race](/wiki/Anglo-
German_naval_arms_race "Anglo-German naval arms race")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/HMS_Dreadnought_1906_H61017.jpg/300px-
HMS_Dreadnought_1906_H61017.jpg)](/wiki/File:HMS_Dreadnought_1906_H61017.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:HMS_Dreadnought_1906_H61017.jpg "Enlarge")

The British _Dreadnought_ (1906) made all battleships obsolete because it had
ten long-range 12-inch big guns, mechanical computer-like range finders, high
speed turbine engines that could make 21 knots, and armour plates 11 inches
thick.

After 1805 the dominance of Britain's Royal Navy was unchallenged; in the
1890s Germany decided to match it. Grand Admiral [Alfred von
Tirpitz](/wiki/Alfred_von_Tirpitz "Alfred von Tirpitz") (1849 – 1930)
dominated German naval policy from 1897 until 1916.[42] Before the Germany
Empire formed in 1871, Prussia never had a real navy, nor did the other German
states. Tirpitz turned the modest little fleet into a world-class force that
could threaten the British Royal Navy. The British responded with new
technology typified by the [Dreadnought
revolution](/wiki/HMS_Dreadnought_\(1906\) "HMS Dreadnought \(1906\)"). It
made every battleship obsolete and, supplemented by the global network of
coaling stations and telegraph cables, enabled Britain to stay well in the
lead in naval affairs.[43][44]

Apart from a determination to retain a strong naval advantage, the British
lacked a military strategy or plans for a major war. [45]

## Economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Economy")]

The Edwardian era stands out as a time of peace and prosperity. There were no
severe depressions, and prosperity was widespread. Britain's growth rate,
manufacturing output and [GDP](/wiki/GDP "GDP") (but not GDP per capita) fell
behind its rivals, the United States and Germany, but the nation still led the
world in trade, finance and shipping, and had strong bases in manufacturing
and mining.[46] The industrial sector was slow to adjust to global changes,
and there was a striking preference for leisure over entrepreneurship among
the elite. However, major achievements should be underlined.
[London](/wiki/London "London") was the financial centre of the world—far more
efficient and wide-ranging than New York, Paris or Berlin. Britain had built
up a vast reserve of overseas credits in its formal Empire, as well as in its
informal empire in Latin America and other nations. It had huge financial
holdings in the United States, especially in railways. These assets proved
vital in paying for supplies in the first years of the World War. The
amenities, especially in urban life, were accumulating—prosperity was highly
visible. The working classes were beginning to protest politically for a
greater voice in government, but the level of industrial unrest on economic
issues was not high until about 1908.[47]

## Social change and improved
health[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Social change and improved health")]

By the late-1880s, the [Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution
"Industrial Revolution") had created new technologies that changed the way
people lived. The growth of industry shifts in manufacturing factories,
special-purpose machinery and technological innovations, which led to
increased productivity. [Gender roles](/wiki/Gender_roles "Gender roles")
shifted as women made use of the new technology to upgrade their lifestyle and
their career opportunities.

Mortality declined steadily in urban England and Wales 1870–1917. Robert
Millward and Frances N. Bell looked statistically at those factors in the
physical environment (especially population density and overcrowding) that
raised death rates directly, as well as indirect factors such as price and
income movements that affected expenditures on sewers, water supplies, food,
and medical staff. The statistical data show that increases in the incomes of
households and increases in town tax revenues helped cause the decline of
mortality. The new money permitted higher spending on food, and also on a wide
range of health-enhancing goods and services such as medical care. The major
improvement in the physical environment was the quality of the housing stock,
which rose faster than the population; its quality was increasingly regulated
by central and local government.[48] [Infant mortality](/wiki/Infant_mortality
"Infant mortality") fell faster in England and Wales than in Scotland. Clive
Lee argues that one factor was the continued overcrowding in Scotland's
housing.[49] During the First World War, infant mortality fell sharply across
the country. J.M. Winter attributes this to the full employment and higher
wages paid to war workers.[50]

### Rising status of
women[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Rising status of women")]

For housewives, sewing machines enabled the production of ready made clothing
and made it easier for women to sew their own clothes; more generally, argues
Barbara Burman, "home dressmaking was sustained as an important aid for women
negotiating wider social shifts and tensions in their lives."[51] Increased
literacy in the [middle-class](/wiki/Middle-class "Middle-class") gave women
wider access to information and ideas. Numerous new magazines appealed to her
tastes and help define femininity.[52]

The inventions of the typewriter, telephone, and new filing systems offered
middle-class women increased employment opportunities.[53][54] So too did the
rapid expansion of the school system,[55] and the emergence of the new
profession of nursing. Education and status led to demands for female roles in
the rapidly expanding world of sports.[56]

Women were very active in church affairs, including attendance at services,
Sunday school teaching, fund raising, pastoral care, social work and support
for international missionary activities. They quietly submitted to their
almost complete exclusion from practically all leadership roles.[57]

#### Women's
suffrage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Women's suffrage")]

Main article: [Women's suffrage in the United
Kingdom](/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_the_United_Kingdom "Women's suffrage in
the United Kingdom")

As middle-class women rose in status they increasingly supported demands for a
political voice.[58][59] There was significant support for woman suffrage in
all the parties, but the Liberal Party was in control after 1906 and a handful
of its leaders, especially [H. H. Asquith](/wiki/H._H._Asquith "H. H.
Asquith"), blocked it.[60]

There were numerous organisations which did their work quietly. After 1897
they were increasingly linked together by the [National Union of Women's
Suffrage Societies](/wiki/National_Union_of_Women%27s_Suffrage_Societies
"National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies") (NUWSS) led by [Millicent
Fawcett](/wiki/Millicent_Fawcett "Millicent Fawcett"). However front page
publicity was seized by the [Women's Social and Political
Union](/wiki/Women%27s_Social_and_Political_Union "Women's Social and
Political Union") (WSPU). Founded in 1903, it was tightly controlled by the
three Pankhursts, [Emmeline Pankhurst](/wiki/Emmeline_Pankhurst "Emmeline
Pankhurst") (1858–1928), and her daughters [Christabel
Pankhurst](/wiki/Christabel_Pankhurst "Christabel Pankhurst") (1880–1958) and
[Sylvia Pankhurst](/wiki/Sylvia_Pankhurst "Sylvia Pankhurst") (1882–1960).[61]
It specialized in highly visible publicity campaigns such as large parades.
This had the effect of energizing all dimensions of the suffrage movement.
While there was a majority of support for suffrage in parliament, the ruling
Liberal Party refused to allow a vote on the issue; the result of which was an
escalation in the suffragette campaign. The WSPU, in dramatic contrast to its
allies, embarked on a campaign of violence to publicize the issue, even to the
detriment of its own aims.[62][63]

#### Birth
control[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Birth control")]

Although abortion was illegal, it was nevertheless the most widespread form of
birth control in use.[64] Used predominantly by [working-class](/wiki/Working-
class "Working-class") women, the procedure was used not only as a means of
terminating pregnancy, but also to prevent poverty and unemployment. Those who
transported [contraceptives](/wiki/Contraceptive "Contraceptive") could be
legally punished. Contraceptives became more expensive over time and had a
high failure rate. Unlike contraceptives, abortion did not need any prior
planning and was less expensive. Newspaper advertisements were used to promote
and sell [abortifacients](/wiki/Abortifacient "Abortifacient") indirectly.[65]

Not all of society was accepting of contraceptives or abortion, and the
opposition viewed both as part of one and the same sin. Abortion was much more
common among the middle-classes than among those living in rural areas, where
the procedure was not readily available. Women were often tricked into
purchasing ineffective pills. In addition to fearing legal reprimands, many
physicians did not condone abortion because they viewed it as an immoral
procedure potentially endangering a woman's life.[65] Because abortion was
illegal and physicians refused to perform the procedure, local women acted as
abortionists, often using crochet hooks or similar instruments.[64]

Feminists of the era focused on educating and finding jobs for women, leaving
aside the controversial issues of contraceptives and abortion, which in
popular opinion were often related to promiscuity and prostitution. The Church
condemned abortion as immoral and a form of rebellion against the child-
bearing role women were expected to assume. Many considered abortion to be a
selfish act that allowed a woman to avoid personal responsibility,
contributing to a decline in moral values.[64] Abortion was often a solution
for women who already had children and did not want more. Consequently, the
size of families decreased drastically.[65]

#### Poverty among working-class
women[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Poverty among working-class women")]

The [1834 Poor Law](/wiki/1834_Poor_Law "1834 Poor Law") defined who could
receive monetary relief. The act reflected and perpetuated prevailing gender
conditions. In Edwardian society, men were the source of wealth. The law
restricted relief for unemployed, able-bodied male workers, due to the
prevailing view that they would find work in the absence of financial
assistance. However, women were treated differently. After the Poor Law was
passed, women and children received most of the aid. The law did not recognise
single independent women, and lumped women and children into the same
category. If a man was physically disabled, his wife was also treated as
disabled under the law. Unmarried mothers were sent to the workhouse,
receiving unfair social treatment such as being restricted from attending
church on Sundays. During marriage disputes women often lost the rights to
their children, even if their husbands were abusive.[66]

At the time, single mothers were the poorest sector in society, disadvantaged
for at least four reasons. First, women had longer lifespans, often leaving
them widowed with children. Second, women's work opportunities were few, and
when they did find work, their wages were lower than male workers' wages.
Thirdly, women were often less likely to marry or remarry after being widowed,
leaving them as the main providers for the remaining family members. Finally,
poor women had deficient diets, because their husbands and children received
disproportionately large shares of food. Many women were malnourished and had
limited access to health care.[66]

#### Female
servants[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Female servants")]

Edwardian Britain had large numbers of male and female [domestic
servants](/wiki/Domestic_servant "Domestic servant"), in both urban and rural
areas.[67] Middle and upper-class women relied on servants to run their homes
smoothly. Servants were provided with food, clothing, housing, and a small
wage, and lived in a self-enclosed social system inside the mansion.[68] The
number of domestic servants fell in the Edwardian era due to a declining
number of young people willing to be employed in this area.[69]

### Fashion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Fashion")]

Main article: [1900s in fashion](/wiki/1900s_in_fashion "1900s in fashion")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c7/Women_dress-1901-1911-Punch.jpg/300px-
Women_dress-1901-1911-Punch.jpg)](/wiki/File:Women_dress-1901-1911-Punch.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Women_dress-1901-1911-Punch.jpg "Enlarge")

cartoon in _Punch_ (1911) compares changes in fashion between 1901 and 1911.
"The dowdy voluminous clothes of the earlier date, making the grandmother an
old lady and the mother seem plain, had been replaced by much simpler looser
wear producing a sense of release for all three females."[70]

The upper-classes embraced leisure sports, which resulted in rapid
developments in fashion, as more mobile and flexible clothing styles were
needed.[71][72] During the Edwardian era, women wore a very tight
[corset](/wiki/Corset "Corset"), or [bodice](/wiki/Bodice "Bodice"), and
dressed in long skirts. The Edwardian era was the last time women wore corsets
in everyday life. According to [Arthur Marwick](/wiki/Arthur_Marwick "Arthur
Marwick"), the most striking change of all the developments that occurred
during the Great War was the modification in women's dress, "for, however far
politicians were to put the clocks back in other steeples in the years after
the war, no one ever put the lost inches back on the hems of women's
skirts".[73]

The Edwardians developed new styles in clothing design.[74] While the
Victorian Era is associated with large, ankle-length, heavy, dark velvet gowns
and bustles for the classes that could afford them, the Edwardian era favored
more tightly fitting skirts and dresses made of lightweight fabrics designed
for a more active lifestyle.[75]

  * The 2 pieces dress came into vogue. Skirts hung tight at the hips and flared at the hem, creating a trumpet of lily-like shape.
  * Skirts in 1901 had decorated hems with ruffles of fabric and lace.
  * Some dresses and skirts featured trains.
  * Tailored jackets, first introduced in 1880, increased in popularity and by 1900, tailored suits became popular.[76]
  * By 1904, skirts became fuller and less clingy.
  * In 1905, skirts fell in soft folds that curved in, then flared out near the hemlines.
  * From 1905 – 1907, waistlines rose.
  * In 1901, the [hobble skirt](/wiki/Hobble_skirt "Hobble skirt") was introduced; a tight fitting skirt that restricted a woman's stride.
  * [Lingerie dresses](/wiki/Lingerie_dress "Lingerie dress"), or tea gowns made of soft fabrics, festooned with ruffles and lace were worn indoors.[77]
  * Around 1913 women's dresses acquired a lower and sometimes V-shaped neckline in opposition to the high collars a generation before. This was considered a scandal and caused an outrage among the clergy throughout Europe.[78]

### Newspapers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Newspapers")]

The turn of the century saw the rise of popular journalism aimed at the lower
middle class and tending to deemphasise highly detailed political and
international news, which remain the focus of a handful of low-circulation
prestige newspapers. They were family-owned and operated, and were primarily
interested not in profits but in influence on the nation's elite by their
control of the news and editorials on serious topics. The new press they
reached vastly larger audiences by emphasis on sports, crime, sensationalism,
and gossip about famous personalities. Detailed accounts of major speeches and
complex international events were not printed. [Alfred Harmsworth, 1st
Viscount Northcliffe](/wiki/Alfred_Harmsworth,_1st_Viscount_Northcliffe
"Alfred Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Northcliffe") was the chief innovator.[79].
He used his _[Daily Mail](/wiki/Daily_Mail "Daily Mail")_ and _[Daily
Mirror](/wiki/Daily_Mirror "Daily Mirror")_ to transform the media along the
American model of "[Yellow Journalism](/wiki/Yellow_Journalism "Yellow
Journalism")". [Lord Beaverbrook](/wiki/Max_Aitken,_1st_Baron_Beaverbrook "Max
Aitken, 1st Baron Beaverbrook") said he was "the greatest figure who ever
strode down Fleet Street".[80] Harmsworth made a great deal of money, but
during the [First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World War") he also
wanted political power. For that he purchased the highest prestige newspaper,
_[The Times](/wiki/The_Times "The Times")_.[81] P. P. Catterall and Colin
Seymour-Ure conclude that:

> More than anyone [he] ... shaped the modern press. Developments he
> introduced or harnessed remain central: broad contents, exploitation of
> advertising revenue to subsidize prices, aggressive marketing, subordinate
> regional markets, independence from party control.[82]

## The arts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: The arts")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Peter_Pan_%282733740964%29.jpg/220px-
Peter_Pan_%282733740964%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Peter_Pan_\(2733740964\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Peter_Pan_\(2733740964\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Peter Pan statue](/wiki/Peter_Pan_statue "Peter Pan statue"), [Kensington
Gardens](/wiki/Kensington_Gardens "Kensington Gardens")

The Edwardian era corresponds to the French _[Belle
Époque](/wiki/Belle_%C3%89poque "Belle Époque")_. Despite its brief pre-
eminence, the period is characterised by its own unique architectural style,
fashion, and lifestyle. [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") had a
particularly strong influence. Artists were influenced by the development of
the automobile and electricity, and a greater awareness of human rights.

In November 1910, [Roger Fry](/wiki/Roger_Fry "Roger Fry") organised the
exhibition _Manet and the Post-Impressionists_ at the [Grafton
Galleries](/wiki/Grafton_Galleries "Grafton Galleries"), London. This
exhibition was the first to prominently feature [Gauguin](/wiki/Gauguin
"Gauguin"), [Manet](/wiki/Manet "Manet"), [Matisse](/wiki/Matisse "Matisse"),
and [Van Gogh](/wiki/Van_Gogh "Van Gogh") in England and brought their art to
the public. He followed it up with the _Second Post-Impressionist Exhibition_
in 1912.

[George Frampton](/wiki/George_Frampton "George Frampton")'s [statue of Peter
Pan](/wiki/Statue_of_Peter_Pan "Statue of Peter Pan"), "erected in Hyde Park
in 1912 ... immediately became a source of contention, sparking debate about
the role of public statuary and its role in spaces of recreation."[83]

### Literature[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Literature")]

In fiction, some of the best-known names are [J. M. Barrie](/wiki/J._M._Barrie
"J. M. Barrie"), [Arnold Bennett](/wiki/Arnold_Bennett "Arnold Bennett"), [G.
K. Chesterton](/wiki/G._K._Chesterton "G. K. Chesterton"), [Joseph
Conrad](/wiki/Joseph_Conrad "Joseph Conrad"), [E. M.
Forster](/wiki/E._M._Forster "E. M. Forster"), [John
Galsworthy](/wiki/John_Galsworthy "John Galsworthy"), [Kenneth
Grahame](/wiki/Kenneth_Grahame "Kenneth Grahame"), [M. R.
James](/wiki/M._R._James "M. R. James"), [Rudyard
Kipling](/wiki/Rudyard_Kipling "Rudyard Kipling"), [James
Joyce](/wiki/James_Joyce "James Joyce"), [D. H. Lawrence](/wiki/D._H._Lawrence
"D. H. Lawrence"), [Edith Nesbit](/wiki/Edith_Nesbit "Edith Nesbit"), [Beatrix
Potter](/wiki/Beatrix_Potter "Beatrix Potter"), [Saki](/wiki/Saki "Saki"),
[George Bernard Shaw](/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw "George Bernard Shaw"), [H. G.
Wells](/wiki/H._G._Wells "H. G. Wells"), and [P. G.
Wodehouse](/wiki/P._G._Wodehouse "P. G. Wodehouse"). Apart from these famous
writers, this was a period when a great number of novels and short stories
were being published, and a significant distinction between
"[highbrow](/wiki/Highbrow "Highbrow")" literature and [popular
fiction](/wiki/Popular_fiction "Popular fiction") emerged. Among the most
famous works of literary criticism was [A. C. Bradley](/wiki/A._C._Bradley "A.
C. Bradley")'s _Shakespearean Tragedy_ (1904). [84]

### Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: Music")]

Live performances, both amateur and professional, were popular. [Henry
Wood](/wiki/Henry_Wood "Henry Wood"), [Edward Elgar](/wiki/Edward_Elgar
"Edward Elgar"), [Gustav Holst](/wiki/Gustav_Holst "Gustav Holst"), [Arnold
Bax](/wiki/Arnold_Bax "Arnold Bax"), [George
Butterworth](/wiki/George_Butterworth "George Butterworth"), [Ralph Vaughan
Williams](/wiki/Ralph_Vaughan_Williams "Ralph Vaughan Williams"), and [Thomas
Beecham](/wiki/Thomas_Beecham "Thomas Beecham") were all active. Military and
brass bands often played outside in parks during the summer.[85] The new
technology of [wax cylinders](/wiki/Wax_cylinders "Wax cylinders") played on
[phonographs](/wiki/Phonograph "Phonograph"), made live performances
permanently available for repetition at any time.

### Performing
arts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=23 "Edit
section: Performing arts")]

Cinema was primitive and audiences preferred live performances to picture
shows. [Music hall](/wiki/Music_hall "Music hall") was very popular and
widespread; influential performers included male impersonator [Vesta
Tilley](/wiki/Vesta_Tilley "Vesta Tilley") and comic [Little
Tich](/wiki/Little_Tich "Little Tich").[86]

The most successful playwright of the era was [W. Somerset
Maugham](/wiki/W._Somerset_Maugham "W. Somerset Maugham"). In 1908, he had
four plays running simultaneously in London, and
_[Punch](/wiki/Punch_\(magazine\) "Punch \(magazine\)")_ published a cartoon
of Shakespeare biting his fingernails nervously as he looked at the
billboards. Maugham's plays, like his novels, usually had a conventional plot
structure, but the decade also saw the rise of the so-called New Drama,
represented in plays by [George Bernard Shaw](/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw
"George Bernard Shaw"), [Harley Granville
Barker](/wiki/Harley_Granville_Barker "Harley Granville Barker"), and
Continental imports by [Henrik Ibsen](/wiki/Henrik_Ibsen "Henrik Ibsen") and
[Gerhardt Hauptmann](/wiki/Gerhardt_Hauptmann "Gerhardt Hauptmann"). The
actor/manager system, as managed by [Sir Henry Irving](/wiki/Sir_Henry_Irving
"Sir Henry Irving"), [Sir George Alexander](/wiki/George_Alexander_\(actor\)
"George Alexander \(actor\)"), and [Sir Herbert Beerbohm
Tree](/wiki/Sir_Herbert_Beerbohm_Tree "Sir Herbert Beerbohm Tree"), was in
decline.

###
Architecture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Architecture")]

See also: [Edwardian architecture](/wiki/Edwardian_architecture "Edwardian
architecture")

Notable architects included [Edwin Lutyens](/wiki/Edwin_Lutyens "Edwin
Lutyens"), [Charles Rennie Mackintosh](/wiki/Charles_Rennie_Mackintosh
"Charles Rennie Mackintosh"), and [Giles Gilbert
Scott](/wiki/Giles_Gilbert_Scott "Giles Gilbert Scott"). In spite of the
popularity of [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") in Europe, the
[Edwardian Baroque](/wiki/Edwardian_Baroque_architecture "Edwardian Baroque
architecture") style of architecture was widely favoured for public structures
and was a revival of [Christopher Wren](/wiki/Christopher_Wren "Christopher
Wren")–inspired designs of the late 17th and early 18th centuries. The change
or reversal in taste from the Victorian eclectic styles corresponded with the
historical revivals of the period, most prominently earlier
[Georgian](/wiki/Georgian_architecture "Georgian architecture") and
[Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture")
styles of the late 18th and early 19th centuries.[87]

[White City Stadium](/wiki/White_City_Stadium "White City Stadium") for the
[1908 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1908_Summer_Olympics "1908 Summer Olympics") was
the first Olympic Stadium in the UK. Built on the site of the [Franco-British
Exhibition](/wiki/Franco-British_Exhibition "Franco-British Exhibition"), it
had a seating capacity of 68,000 was opened by King Edward VII on 27 April
1908. It was the largest structure of its type in the world, and was designed
to be awesome and enhance the love of large-scale spectacle that characterised
Edwardian London.[88]

### Film[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Film")]

Filmmakers [Mitchell and Kenyon](/wiki/Mitchell_and_Kenyon "Mitchell and
Kenyon") documented many scenes from Britain and Ireland from 1900–1907,
sports, parades, factory exits, parks, city streets, boating and the like.
Their films have fortunately survived in very good quality restored from the
original negatives.[89][90]

## Science and
technology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Science and technology")]

The period featured many innovations. [Ernest
Rutherford](/wiki/Ernest_Rutherford "Ernest Rutherford") published his studies
on [radioactivity](/wiki/Radioactivity "Radioactivity"). The first
transatlantic wireless signals were sent by [Guglielmo
Marconi](/wiki/Guglielmo_Marconi "Guglielmo Marconi"), and the [Wright
brothers](/wiki/Wright_brothers "Wright brothers") flew for the first
time.[91]

By the end of the era, [Louis Blériot](/wiki/Louis_Bl%C3%A9riot "Louis
Blériot") had crossed the [English Channel](/wiki/English_Channel "English
Channel") by air; the largest ship in the world, [RMS
_Olympic_](/wiki/RMS_Olympic "RMS Olympic"), had sailed on its maiden voyage
and her larger sister [RMS _Titanic_](/wiki/RMS_Titanic "RMS Titanic") was
under construction; automobiles were common; and the [South
Pole](/wiki/South_Pole "South Pole") was reached for the first time by [Roald
Amundsen](/wiki/Roald_Amundsen "Roald Amundsen")'s and then [Robert Falcon
Scott](/wiki/Robert_Falcon_Scott "Robert Falcon Scott")'s teams.

## Sport[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: Sport")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/London_1908_Steeplechasea.jpg/200px-
London_1908_Steeplechasea.jpg)](/wiki/File:London_1908_Steeplechasea.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:London_1908_Steeplechasea.jpg "Enlarge")

1908 Summer Olympics in London: The water jump in the
[steeplechase](/wiki/Steeplechase_\(athletics\) "Steeplechase \(athletics\)")

The [1908 Summer Olympic Games](/wiki/1908_Summer_Olympics "1908 Summer
Olympics") were held in London. Popularity of sports tended to conform to
class divisions, with tennis and yachting popular among the very wealthy and
[football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") favoured by the
working class.[92]

### Football[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Edwardian_era&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Football")]

[Aston Villa](/wiki/Aston_Villa "Aston Villa") maintained their position as
the pre-eminent football team of the era, winning the [FA Cup](/wiki/FA_Cup
"FA Cup") for the fourth time in 1904–05 and their sixth League title in
1909–10. The club colours of claret and sky blue were adopted by
[Burnley](/wiki/Burnley_FC "Burnley FC") as a tribute to their success in
1910. Sunderland achieved their fourth league title in 1901–02. The era also
saw [Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool_F.C. "Liverpool F.C.") (1900–01, 1905–06),
[Newcastle United](/wiki/Newcastle_United "Newcastle United") (1904–05,
1906–07, 1908–09) and [Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C.
"Manchester United F.C.") (1907–08) winning their first league titles.[93]
